title: 115_hr5000
content: The "Free to Fly Act" is the short title of this legislation. It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. Section 40102(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include provisions regarding the citizenship requirements for individuals and organizations involved in the aviation industry. In amending Section 40102(a) of title 49, United States Code, citizenship requirements for individuals and organizations in the aviation industry are revised to include those not organized under US laws or a State, the District of Columbia, or a US territory or possession. This change also expands the definition of a citizen of the United States to include individuals or entities organized under US laws or a State, the District of Columbia, or a US territory or possession. The requirement for a certificate is outlined in Section 3. Section 41101(b) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include additional requirements for non-citizens operating certain routes. This includes individuals organized under the laws of the United States or a State, the District of Columbia, or a territory or possession of the United States. All employees and managing officers, excluding the board of directors, must be US citizens, nationals, or lawful permanent residents, with headquarters and base of operations in the US. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATES OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE. Section 41102 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary of Transportation to issue a certificate of public convenience and necessity to a person not under the actual control of U.S. citizens or with a majority ownership by non-U.S. citizens. The Secretary of Transportation can issue a certificate of public convenience and necessity to a person with ownership or control by non-U.S. citizens for air transportation services as an air carrier, temporary air transportation, or charter air transportation. The amendment also includes provisions for Presidential review of certain certificates. The Secretary of Transportation can issue certificates for foreign air transportation or interstate/intrastate air transportation by non-U.S. citizens, subject to Presidential review. SEC. 5. CIVIL RESERVE AIR FLEET ELIGIBILITY. Amends Section 41106 of title 49, United States Code, allowing the Secretary of Defense to contract with an air carrier that does not meet all requirements under certain conditions. SEC. 6. APPLICATION FOR CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE. Section 41108 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include other persons organized under US laws in addition to citizens. The amendments also expand the scope of interstate air transportation regulations to cover non-citizens and foreign air transportation. SEC. 7 amends Section 41110(a)(2)(B) of title 49, US Code. SEC. 8 updates Section 41112(a) regarding liability insurance. SEC. 9 involves presidential review of foreign air carriers and non-citizens. SEC. 9 amends Section 41307 of title 49, US Code, regarding presidential review of foreign air carriers and non-citizens. SEC. 10 updates Section 41503 on joint pricing. SEC. 11 amends Section 41703(a) of title 49, US Code, regarding navigation of foreign civil aircraft. It allows for specific authorization under sections 41102 and 41108 if the airman holds a valid certificate issued by the Government. SEC. 12 deals with waivers for non-citizen air carrier participation in the Civil Reserve Air Fleet. The Secretary of Defense has the authority to waive citizenship requirements for non-citizen air carriers and their aircraft for up to two years, with the option for renewal. The air carrier must be owned by a non-US citizen organized under US laws. The Secretary of Defense can waive citizenship requirements for non-citizen air carriers and their aircraft for up to two years, with the option for renewal, as long as the carrier is owned by a non-US citizen organized under US laws. The carrier must also hold a certificate of public convenience and necessity under section 41102 of title 49. Non-citizen air carriers can be granted waiver authority by the Secretary of Defense for up to two years, with the possibility of renewal, if owned by a non-US citizen organized under US laws and holding a certificate of public convenience and necessity under section 41102 of title 49.
